Dialogue.NPCText:
Before you crouches a weathered man, face painted with streaks of earth and bone, one ear mangled and missing. A wolf-bone mask hangs at his side. He glances at you with animal suspicion.

"You move like a startled rabbit. Speak your business—unless you'd rather gnaw grass in silence."

Option.text: Is it true you speak with beasts?
You seem troubled. What plagues you?
I’ll leave you to your den, wolf.

Dialogue.NPCText:
He snorts, scratching behind his ear.
"I am Tarn, called One-Ear by pups and fools. Trained every wolf and bird in these woods. Animals tell no lies, unlike men. If you listen, you'll learn more from a hawk's shriek than a council of elders."

Option.text: Can you teach me to listen?

Dialogue.NPCText:
Tarn grins, showing a chipped canine.
"Every beast has a voice, if you’re not too much of a crow to listen. Wolves, birds, even snakes—none gossip as much as humans. Maybe you'd learn a thing or two with mud between your toes instead of boots."

Option.text: Teach me the way of the wolf.

Dialogue.NPCText: "People hunt for sport. Beasts hunt to live. Which do you trust in the dark—the honest predator, or the smiling man with a knife behind his back? I’d take the fangs over the forked tongue."

Option.text: I see your point. What troubles you?
Not all people are like that.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Tarn tilts his head, appraising you like a wary hawk.
"You wish to walk among the pack? Patience, rabbit. Listen, then fetch what is needed. But first—you must prove your nose is keener than your tongue."

He shrugs.
"Maybe you’re a dog among wolves. But words are only wind—deeds, not chatter, prove loyalty."

Option.text: What deed would prove my loyalty?

Dialogue.NPCText:
Tarn’s face grows grim.
"One of my best—Brak, a dire wolf—has gone wild. Minax’s taint festers in his blood. Now he roams, a beast-thing, savage and lost. Brak was pack, once. Now he’s a curse stalking our groves."

"Do you wear fangs, or speak with them? Will you help—hunt him down, heal him, or end his pain?"

Option.text: I will help you find Brak.

Dialogue.NPCText:
"Three paths, three hearts:
• Purify: Seek root and spirit, cleanse the taint—but risk your own soul.
• Tame: Win Brak’s trust with wit and meat, but he’ll never be the same.
• Kill: End his pain, swift as a striking hawk.
Each path has claws, rabbit. How do you run?"

Option.text: Give me the tools. I'll hunt Brak.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Tarn hands you a bundle of tokens: a twisted bone whistle, a sprig of spirit-root, and a sharpened stone knife.

"Find Brak in the twisted grove west of camp. Choose your path—call him with the whistle (tame), use the root and ritual to purify him, or end his misery. Bring proof: a fang (if slain), a wolf-token (if tamed), or a spirit-feather (if purified)."

Option.text: I'll find Brak and choose his fate.
Maybe I'm not the right one for this.

Dialogue.NPCText: "The woods will watch. Return when you carry Brak’s fate on your hands. Until then, walk softly, rabbit."

Option.text: I'll return with news of Brak.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Tarn’s eyes narrow as you approach.
"You’ve the look of one changed by the wilds. Have you faced Brak? Show me what you carry."

Option.text: I tamed Brak; he is wild, but no longer lost.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Tarn bows his head, silent a long moment.
"Sometimes, the best hound must be loosed. You ended his pain—quick and clean. I will honor Brak’s memory.
Take this, and let your own spirit run free."

Tarn’s mouth quirks in a rare smile.
"You won the wild, and made a friend. Brak will not be the wolf he was—but neither are you. Take this: a token of the pack’s respect. Return, and the beasts will remember your scent."

Tarn’s eyes glisten with pride.
"You risked your spirit for another’s. Brak’s howl echoes pure in the night again. You have the blessing of grove and beast alike. Take this—rare as a white stag’s step."

Tarn inclines his head, wolf-like.
"Walk in shadow and sun, friend. May the pack watch your path."

Tarn huffs, eyes narrowing like a wolf assessing a stranger.

"Most just want the hunt. Few ask the tale behind the scars. Fine. Sit. But know this—every word you dig up is one more root that binds you here."

Option.text: Were you always part of the Verdant Tribes?
Why do you trust animals more than people?

Dialogue.NPCText:
He taps the jagged edge of his missing ear.

"Taken by a raven—a real one, not metaphor. Was young, full of noise and no sense. Climbed the whispering cliffs to steal a hawk’s egg. Mother bird didn’t appreciate it."

"Lost my balance. Lost my pride. Kept the egg, though. Named him Ruk. He still flies the skies, somewhere. Smarter than me, most days."

Tarn leans back, resting his staff across his knees.
"Was born in the ash-shadow of a Minax-scorched grove. My kin were rootless, drifting—until the Verdant called me. I followed a spirit-lizard into the glade. The elders said it was a sign."

"They gave me a tent and a task: learn the tongue of the beast. So I did. Still do. Every day they teach me new things—growls, hisses, silence."

Option.text: You were chosen by a spirit?
So the Verdant took you in?

Dialogue.NPCText:
He nods solemnly.
"Bright green scales, eyes like polished amber. It curled around my leg, hissed once, then walked toward the trees. I followed for hours. When I stopped, I was surrounded by druids. They weren’t surprised to see me."
"Not all tribes are born of blood. Some are chosen by claw, song, or chance. I earned my place—not by blade, but by understanding the silence between howls. That’s where real power lies."

Tarn’s lip curls slightly.
"A hawk doesn’t stab you in the back. A wolf doesn’t promise safety, then abandon you. Beasts are honest—violent, maybe, but true."

"Minax... she poisoned men. But no beast followed her willingly. Even they know wrongness when it walks in skin."

Option.text: Still, we must work with others.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Tarn sighs.
"Yes, yes. Even a lone wolf joins the pack to eat. I don’t enjoy it, but I understand it. Just keep your fangs bared where I can see them, rabbit."

His expression darkens briefly.

"Had a mate, once. Elya. She danced with the wind and sang to frogs. Lost her to swamp-fever before the rains came. I left after that. Wandered with beasts until the world made sense again."

"Now the pack is all I need. But sometimes… sometimes I hear her in the toadsong."

Option.text: Do you still speak to her?

Dialogue.NPCText:
He nods, quietly.
"Once every season, I sit at the old roots where she danced. If the frogs sing low, I know she listens. Grief isn’t a wound. It’s a footprint. It reminds us where we’ve been."

Option.text: You speak more poetry than I expected.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Tarn snorts.
"Don’t mistake my growl for ignorance. Even wolves sing, if you listen right."

Option.text: Thank you for sharing your story.
